detail.title: Information Flow, Volatility and Fat-Tailed Distribution of Cryptocurrencies: An Empirical Analysis
detail.abstract: This study investigates whether the nonnormality of unconditional return distribution is due to volatility persistence created by random arrival of information. Employing the stable-GARCH model, it examines the information impact on the return and volatility of cryptocurrencies after adjusting for heteroskedasticity. The findings show that information flow significantly and positively affects volatility, while negatively influences tail heaviness of cryptocurrency return distribution. After considering the random arrival of information within trading days, the return distribution is still heavy tailed in calendar days. It provides practical implications for diversification, asset pricing and risk management in cryptocurrency markets.

detail.abstract:
This document contains a sample of the book The Berber Question: A Chapter in the History of North Africa. It includes the table of contents, the prologue, the introduction, and the first section, titled The Berber Paradigm: Synopsis of an Entelechy.

The work offers a critical reassessment of the dominant historiographical paradigm (G. Camps, M. Hachid, etc.) and places the so-called “Berber question” within the long-term historical development of North Africa.

It traces the cultural and migratory movements that, from the eastern Sahel and the Horn of Africa, were projected towards the Nile corridor, the central-western Sahara, and the Atlas arc.

Based on medieval Arab sources (J. M. Cuoq) and the observations of Ibn Khaldun in his Histoire des Berbères, the book proposes a new interpretation of the “Berberization” process, linked to the expansion of Arabo-Eritrean-Somali camel-herding peoples and the consequent rehumanization of the Saharan space between the 3rd and 7th centuries AD.

title: The Tug of War Between AI Innovation and Intellectual Property: Striking the Right Balance
affiliations: Central University of South Bihar and Central University of South Bihar

detail.title: The Tug of War Between AI Innovation and Intellectual Property: Striking the Right Balance
detail.abstract: In the contemporary era of technological breakthroughs, the development of AI is viewed as a dual-edged innovation, offering both benefits and challenges. Its ubiquitous presence is evident in applications ranging from personalised shopping recommendations to music creation. AI, a machine-based system that was designed to mimic human cognitive function, makes recommendations, predictions, and other outputs for a given set of human-defined objectives. The creation and protection of AI, along with AI-generated work, intersect with IPR. An individual whose intellect is behind the creation of AI is granted the exclusive right to utilise their creations. However, the ownership of AI-generated works remains uncertain, raising questions about AI's ability to legally 'create'. This ambiguity is particularly evident in India, where statutory regulations governing AI are yet to be established. Canada, for example, granted copyright protection to RAGHAV, an AI tool that created a painting, whereas that application was rejected in the USA and India. Since AI lacks personhood, it undermines human creators who invest time, effort, and emotions in their work if ownership is granted. Instead, IP rights should be given to human who uses their creative skills to innovate with AI. So, AI should be given recognition and not ownership and authorship. This paper critically examines the intersection of AI and IPR, evaluating existing legal frameworks, challenges, and the implications of granting or denying AI an authorship right. By analysing international perspectives and legal trends, it seeks to contribute to the ongoing discourse on AI's place in intellectual property law.

detail.title: Will Carbon Emission Trading Policy Affect China's Global Resource Allocation?- Based on the Pilot Carbon Emission Trading Policy and Provincial Data in China
detail.abstract: This study takes China as a case to explore the impact of carbon emission trading policies on global resource allocation, which is measured by their influence on outward foreign direct investment (OFDI) and inward foreign direct investment (IFDI). As the world's second-largest economy, China not only has a large scale of foreign investment and foreign capital attraction, but also is the world's largest carbon dioxide emitter. Therefore, how China adjusts global resource allocation through carbon emission trading policies is of great theoretical and practical significance. This study selects the panel data of 28 provinces and cities in China from 2006 to 2020, and uses the difference-in-differences (DID) method to empirically analyze the impact of carbon emission policies on OFDI and IFDI. The results show that the carbon emission trading policy has a significant promoting effect on both OFDI and IFDI. However, this policy has no significant impact on the eastern region, while it has a significant promoting effect on OFDI in the central region and IFDI in the western region. Moreover, the rationalization and upgrading of industrial structure play a regulatory role in the impact of carbon emission policies on OFDI and IFDI. This finding provides new evidence for studying the impact of carbon emission trading policies on global resource allocation, and also provides valuable policy implications for China and other countries when implementing carbon emission trading policies.

Based on a sample of 106 crowdfunding projects and 3315 investors on Dreammove platform in China, results indicate that lead investor’s and followers’ prominence are significantly positive to equity crowdfunding performance. title: High-Speed Rail Expansion and the Fundamental Law of Highway Congestion
affiliations: University of Chicago - Harris School of Public Policy

detail.title: High-Speed Rail Expansion and the Fundamental Law of Highway Congestion
detail.abstract: This paper studies the impact of high-speed rail (HSR) expansion on highway congestion in China. I exploit the staggered rollout of HSR services across cities between 2013 and 2019. Employing a staggered difference-indifferences strategy, I find that HSR connectivity significantly and persistently reduces highway congestion: congested road length declines by 5.8% and a congestion delay index based on travel speed decreases by 6.7%. Mechanism analysis reveals substantial modal substitution from intercity road passenger transport to rail, while freight traffic in rail remains largely unchanged. The effect is strongest in cities where highways are located farther from population centers and serve primarily long-distance travel. The results provide a context-specific test of "Fundamental Law of Road Congestion" (Down's law) and indicate that infrastructure-induced congestion effects may vary in settings where highways primarily serve long-distance, inelastic travel demand.

title: Multi-Scale Characterization of Potentially Toxic Elements in Soils Impacted by Titanium Smelting: Insights into Cross-Site Pollution from Mineralogical Evidence and Receptor Modeling

detail.title: Multi-Scale Characterization of Potentially Toxic Elements in Soils Impacted by Titanium Smelting: Insights into Cross-Site Pollution from Mineralogical Evidence and Receptor Modeling
detail.abstract: Titanium dioxide has gained increasing attention as an emerging pollutant due to its distinctive structural properties and environmental toxicology. However, the environmental impacts of titanium smelting, particularly on soil geochemical characteristics and surrounding environment quality, remain poorly understood. This study systematically investigated the distribution patterns and sources of potentially toxic elements (PTEs) in soil at an abandoned titanium smelter, utilizing integrated mineralogical characterization and receptor modeling analysis. The results revealed pronounced spatial heterogeneity in PTE distribution and mineral assemblages. Elevated Ti concentrations, which were strongly linked to ilmenite-rich mineral phases, and sulfuric acid leakage were the primary contributors to environmental burdens in the titanium smelting area. Chronic soil acidification exacerbated the dissolution of host minerals, thereby enhancing mineral liberation and potential mobility of Cd, Co, Pb, and Zn. Ilmenite, barite, and gypsum emerged as key titanium smelting-affected indicative minerals, underscoring their dual role as environmental burdens and potential resources. Contrastingly, cross-site pollution inputs led to elevated As, Cd, Pb, and Zn levels in non-smelting soil, as evidenced by transportation-related enrichment of hematite, mullite, hemimorphite, sphalerite, and arsenopyrite. This study provides the first comprehensive assessment of environmental impact of titanium smelting activities on site soil quality and emphasizes the cross-site pollution, offering valuable insights for remediation and sustainable redevelopment of abandoned titanium smelting sites.

title: Publicly Funded Immunization Programs in Canada: A Review of Vaccine Adoption Decisions 1996-2020

detail.title: Publicly Funded Immunization Programs in Canada: A Review of Vaccine Adoption Decisions 1996-2020
detail.abstract: Background: Publicly funded immunization programs in Canada play an important role in combating infectious diseases. However, there is limited evidence on how public health authorities determine which vaccines to reimburse, how long it takes to decide, and how vaccines are procured. Methods: First, we describe public vaccine assessment and reimbursement procedures in Canada. Next, we examine the public funding status of each vaccine approved for use in Canada in the last 25 years. For funded vaccines, we calculate timelines from market authorization to national recommendations and public funding.Results: 115 vaccines were approved in Canada between 1996-2020. Of these, 86% belonged to vaccine classes that are currently publicly funded in at least one Canadian province. On average, national recommendations for public reimbursement of new vaccines are issued 22 months after vaccine approval, and 10 months for first-in-class vaccines. For public program implementation, there is on average a 31-month lag (range: 4-61) between approval and first provincial listing for vaccines. There is also marked interprovincial variations in the uptake of new vaccines, with average listing times ranging from 29-66 months. Time-to-adoption also varied by the age group for which the vaccine is targeted, as well as before and after the implementation of the National Immunization Strategy in 2004.Conclusions: The findings of this study point to an opportunity in Canada to improve access time and reduce disparities in access to vaccines. Future studies should seek to identify the root causes of current delays and disparities, and develop frameworks to increase timely access to vaccines.

detail.title: Machine Learning-Driven Modeling Framework for Steam Co-Gasification Applications
detail.abstract: Steam co-gasification of biomass and plastic waste is a promising route for syngas production and waste valorization. However, accurately predicting syngas composition remains challenging due to inherent complexity and nonlinearity of the process. This study presents a comprehensive comparative analysis between conventional process simulators-based models (Aspen Plus), namely the thermodynamic equilibrium (TEM), restricted thermodynamic (RTM), and kinetic (KM) modelling approaches, and machine learning (ML) models for the prediction of the syngas composition. Using 208 experimental data points compiled from 20 published studies covering various feedstocks and gasification conditions in bubbling fluidized bed gasifiers, the performance of the models was evaluated after extensive data preprocessing. Among several ML algorithms evaluated, the neural network (NN) delivered the lowest average root mean square error in syngas mol fraction predictions (0.0174), outperforming RTM (0.0966), KM (0.1378), and TEM (0.1470). To explore input–output relationships beyond interpolation, a conditional generative adversarial network generated synthetic data, which served as the basis for sensitivity and interpretability analyses. The NN, acting as a surrogate model, was paired with SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) and Partial Dependence Plots (PDP) to quantify the effects and nonlinear interactions of key features on syngas yields providing actionable insights for process optimization.

The model allows for measurement error in the administrative data and linkage error as well as survey measurement error. We find several cross-national similarities in error structure but also intriguing differences in error component probabilities, means, and dispersions.

detail.title: Quantifying the Misalignment between National and Local Climate Action Plans

keywords: national energy and climate action plan

detail.abstract: Local climate action plans are often developed independently of their national counterparts which could lead to a misalignment between climate strategies. This study examines the extent of such misalignment using Spain and the city of Vitoria-Gasteiz as a case study. The measures of Spain’s National Energy and Climate Plan and the Climate City Contract of Vitoria-Gasteiz are compared to identify areas of overlap and divergence. Furthermore, national targets relevant at the local level are spatially disaggregated to estimate corresponding municipal targets. The analysis reveals that, of the 110 national measures, 34 identify municipalities as responsible actors, yet only 21 are reflected in Vitoria-Gasteiz’s plan. In addition, 14 local measures align with national ones despite no explicit national assignment of local responsibility, while six local measures have no equivalent in the national plan. Disaggregated targets reveal that the local targets are, on average, over 50% less ambitious than national expectations. The case study findings highlight a potential significant gap in vertical coordination, suggesting that stronger integration of local authorities in national climate action planning is essential for achieving aligned and effective climate action.

title: Benchmarking Urban Sustainability and Resilience: Introducing the Megacity Sustainability Index

detail.title: Benchmarking Urban Sustainability and Resilience: Introducing the Megacity Sustainability Index
detail.abstract: Megacities are vital for understanding global sustainability and resilience. Despite increasing interest in assessing progress toward sustainability, no indicator framework exists for comprehensively assessing and comparing sustainable development across megacities. This study introduces a multi-indicator Megacity Sustainability Index (MSI) that benchmarks sustainability conditions for the 42 world’s megacities (32 established; 10 emerging). Four research questions guided this study: (i) Could a subset of freely accessible, common indicators be used to formulate a simple, robust index that captures the core realms of sustainable development– environment, social, and economic– in megacities? (ii) Do spatial patterns of development emerge based on the MSI? (iii) What statistical associations exist between the MSI, four key global change metrics, and the corrective measure? (iv) What defines the development progress of thriving megacities versus lagging ones? The MSI was created using an 11 sub-metric optimum, including a novel corrective measure metric, to represent the tripartite of sustainability. MSI values ranged from 24 (Nanjing) to 79 (Paris), with no cities scoring in the “very poor” or “very good” categories. Other high performing cities included London, Tokyo, New York, and Osaka; other low performers were Shanghai, Tianjin, Guangzhou-Shenzhen, Lagos, and Lahore. MSI positively correlated with income, education, healthcare access, and infrastructure density, and negatively with population density and growth. The MSI is not simply an assessment tool- it is a prototype for a broader shift toward global-level systems thinking in sustainable urbanization. As global challenges intensify, progress toward sustainability will be shaped not only within cities but through them.

title: Environmental Assessment of Energy Structure Transition
affiliations: Tianjin University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Tianjin University

detail.title: Environmental Assessment of Energy Structure Transition
detail.abstract: Energy structure transition is a long-term evolution towards low-carbon, clean, and reliable energy consumption, which is closely linked to national carbon reduction targets and the sustainable development of human societies. It calls for the construction of a scientific approach that synergises multidimensional objectives to assess its economic, social, and environmental benefits. This special issue brings widely different perspectives with the mutual aim of providing technical improvements and empirical research, moving a valuable step forward in developing a research agenda for sustainable development. We believe that the innovative insights gained from the studies included in this report can promote cooperation between researchers and practitioners in the energy sector, whether in scientific theory or policy practice.

title: The Impact of Voluntary Environmental Regulation on Environmental Performance of Heavily Polluting Enterprises: Game Analysis and Econometric Test
affiliations: Dalian University and Dalian University

detail.title: The Impact of Voluntary Environmental Regulation on Environmental Performance of Heavily Polluting Enterprises: Game Analysis and Econometric Test
detail.abstract: Voluntary environmental regulation is a key institutional arrangement to fulfill environmental responsibilities actively. Exploring how it affects the environmental performance of heavily polluting enterprises is of great significance for practicing high-level environmental protection. Innovatively combining four-party evolutionary game analysis and econometric test methods, this paper explores the impact and mechanism of voluntary environmental regulation on the environmental performance of heavily polluting enterprises from both theoretical and empirical dimensions. The research findings are as follows: (1) The implementation of voluntary environmental regulation can effectively improve the environmental performance of heavily polluting enterprises, but its effect depends on the synergy of multiple parties. (2) Local ecological environment bureaus strengthen the regulatory intensity and enhance the incentive and disciplinary mechanisms to establish institutional constraints. Media exposure forms information constraints by optimizing the communication mechanism and strengthening the response of environmental issues. Both of them enhance the effectiveness of voluntary environmental regulation and promote the improvement of the environmental performance of heavily polluting enterprises. Strict regulation by local ecological environment bureaus and the exposure by media forms the key institutional guarantee and external driving force respectively for the effective operation of voluntary environmental regulation. (3) Heavily polluting enterprises establish internal constraints by increasing environmental protection investment and raising pollution control costs, which provides fundamental support and serves as the core endogenous driving force to promote environmental performance. (4) In contrast, voluntary environmental regulation enhance public trust in heavily polluting enterprises through the mechanism of information disclosure and reputation linkage. This restructures the logic of public reporting participation and weakens the monitoring motivation. The public tends to adopt a non-reporting strategy, which plays a relatively limited role in the process of voluntary environmental regulation influencing the environmental performance of heavily polluting enterprises. This research provides theoretical support and practical basis for enhancing the environmental performance of heavily polluting enterprises and achieving high-level environmental protection.

title: Postnatal Pesticide Exposure and Executive Function in Children and Adolescents: Findings from South Africa
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Basel - Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute, University of Basel - Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute, University of Basel - Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute, University of Basel - Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Basel - Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Basel - Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute and University of Cape Town (UCT)

detail.title: Postnatal Pesticide Exposure and Executive Function in Children and Adolescents: Findings from South Africa
detail.abstract: IntroductionResearch on the impact of postnatal pesticide exposure on executive functioning (EF) in children remains limited globally especially in African agricultural contexts. This study investigated associations between urinary pesticide biomarkers and EF in the CapSA cohort.MethodsData from 445 participants (mean age: 10.6 years; 55.3% male) were analysed. EF was assessed using three Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery (CANTAB) subtests: the Multitasking Test (MTT, cognitive flexibility), Rapid Visual Information Processing (RVP, inhibitory control), and Spatial Working Memory (SWM, visuospatial working memory). Average levels of 13 pesticide biomarkers—spanning insecticides (organophosphates, pyrethroids), fungicides (dithiocarbamates, triazoles, succinate dehydrogenase inhibitors), and herbicides (phenoxy acids)—were calculated from two spot urine samples collected in 2017 and 2019. Associations between specific gravity-adjusted, log10-transformed biomarker-levels (ng/mL) and EF z-scores were estimated using multivariate linear regression, adjusting for agricultural setting, child and maternal characteristics, and household factors.ResultsMost biomarkers were detected in over half of samples; 3,5,6-trichloro-2-psyridinol (TCPy) and 3-phenoxybenzoic (3-PBA) acid were nearly ubiquitous. Higher average levels of TCPy (β=–0.14; 95%CI: -0.27, -0.01) and 4-bromo-2-chlorophenol (BCP,–0.08; -0.15, -0.02) were associated with poorer cognitive flexibility. Higher average levels of TCPy (–0.18; -0.31, -0.05), BCP (–0.08; -0.14, -0.01), cis-3-(2,2-dichlorovinyl)-2,2-dimethylcyclopropane carboxylic acid (cis-DCCA,–0.15; -0.31, 0.00), and 4-Hydroxy-Pyrimethanil (OH-P; –0.09; -0.16, -0.03) were associated with poorer inhibitory control. No significant associations were observed for visuospatial working memory.ConclusionsFindings suggest postnatal exposure to organophosphates, pyrethroids and triazoles may impair specific EF domains. Research incorporating pesticide biomonitoring and targeted interventions in agricultural populations is required.

title: Fre-Va: Frequency Variational Autoencoder for Addressing Frequency Bias in Super-Resolution
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Xinjiang University, Xinjiang University, Xinjiang University, Xinjiang University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Guangzhou University of Chinese Medicine - School of Basic Medical Science

detail.title: Fre-Va: Frequency Variational Autoencoder for Addressing Frequency Bias in Super-Resolution
detail.abstract: Single Image Super-Resolution (SISR) aims to reconstruct high-resolution (HR) images from low-resolution (LR) counterparts, but existing models often exhibit spectral bias, excessively relying on low-frequency (LF) information while inadequately recovering high-frequency (HF) details. Although various frequency-domain methods have been proposed to mitigate this issue, effectively capturing stable HF textures remains challenging. Inspired by recent insights into frequency-domain analysis, we introduce Fre-VA, a novel frequency-aware Variational Autoencoder designed explicitly to address the spectral bias problem in SISR. In contrast to conventional methods, Fre-VA explicitly maintains separate processing streams for LF and HF features throughout the network. By leveraging full-frequency images as bridges, the proposed framework learns the joint correlation distribution between LF and HF components instead of directly regressing unpredictable HF textures. Experimental evaluations on five benchmark datasets demonstrate that Fre-VA consistently surpasses state-of-the-art methods, significantly improving the reconstruction fidelity of high-frequency details. This work presents a promising step toward robust, frequency-balanced super-resolution models capable of reliable high-frequency restoration.

title: Rad-Som: An Adaptive Hybrid Rbfnn-Som Model for Enhanced Supervised Learning and Mapping
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Rad-Som: An Adaptive Hybrid Rbfnn-Som Model for Enhanced Supervised Learning and Mapping
detail.abstract: Self-Organizing Maps (SOMs) are widely used for data classification, mapping, and visualization because of their ability to reveal patterns in feature space. Meanwhile, Radial Basis Function Neural Networks (RBFNNs), thanks to their simple structure, rapid learning capability, and ability to model nonlinear systems, have demonstrated their effectiveness in solving data science classification and regression challenges. Determining the optimal number of neurons, their center vectors, and radial function widths remains a challenging task for these networks. This study introduces a novel approach, named RAD-SOM, that combines the strengths of RBFNNs with the mapping and visualization capabilities of self-organizing maps. The proposed method offers an efficient solution for classifying, mapping, and visualizing data patterns in feature space. By utilizing a growing Self-Organizing Map (SOM) framework and adaptive parameter tuning inspired by parameterless SOMs, the proposed method dynamically adjusts the network structure while enhancing classification accuracy and interpretability. The proposed approach is evaluated against several benchmark datasets. It surpasses traditional SOM-based classifiers and standard RBFNNs in classification performance and feature space visualization, presenting a robust, efficient, and transparent solution for complex data analysis tasks.

title: Variation-Aware Proxy Learning for Semantic Segmentation
affiliations: Inha University and Inha University

detail.title: Variation-Aware Proxy Learning for Semantic Segmentation
detail.abstract: In semantic segmentation, accurately modeling intra-class variance is essential for capturing fine-grained details and resolving ambiguity near class boundaries. While existing proxy-based embedding methods represent each class with a single prototype, they struggle to reflect diverse intra-class structures, especially in complex scenes. In this paper, we propose a novel representation learning framework called Variation-Aware Proxy Learning, which introduces a representative proxy to encode shared class semantics and multiple variation vectors to capture fine-grained intra-class variations. These components are integrated through a factorized similarity score, enabling more expressive and discriminative embedding structures. To further enhance learning in ambiguous regions, we introduce focal modulation and design a new Compositional Similarity Loss composed of attraction and repulsion terms that adaptively amplify the contribution of hard examples. Our method is model-agnostic and requires no additional inference-time cost. Extensive experiments across multiple segmentation benchmarks—Cityscapes, COCO-Stuff10k, and iSAID—and diverse backbones including CNNs and Transformers, demonstrate consistent improvements in mIoU and boundary precision, particularly in challenging regions with high intra-class variability.

title: Abnormal Returns of Corporations Adopting Bitcoin as a Treasury Asset: An Event Study
affiliations: Erasmus University Rotterdam (EUR) - Erasmus School of Economics (ESE)

detail.title: Abnormal Returns of Corporations Adopting Bitcoin as a Treasury Asset: An Event Study
detail.abstract:
From early 2020 through into 2021, Bitcoin's emergence as a new asset class has garnered serious attention. Despite one of the most tumultuous years in recent memory, dozens of firms begun to announce purchases or acquisitions of bitcoins in lieu of holding fiat currencies. This surge in interest has followed much of the existing literature on Bitcoin being limited to topics such as portfolio construction, volatility and the returns of Bitcoin. However, there is currently no published literature investigating corporate acquisition of Bitcoin and the effects these announcements may have on the shares of firms once made public to the market. This paper is the first event study to investigate the effects of abnormal returns across publicly traded firms, following a market announcement of the purchase or acquisition of Bitcoin as a treasury asset and/or holding.

Event study methodology consistent with that of Fama et al.(1969); Strong (1992) and MacKinlay (1997) will be utilised in order to construct event windows of 20 days on either side of an announcement date (a 41-day event window), and five days either side of an announcement date (an 11-day event window). These test the cumulative abnormal returns (CARs) of 18 different events that occurred across 2020-2021, where firms announced Bitcoin holdings.

title: Geometric Symmetry in EUR/USD and S&P 500 - Anomaly or Design?
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Geometric Symmetry in EUR/USD and S&P 500 - Anomaly or Design?

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no personal or financial conflicts of interest related to the content of this study. The research was conducted independently and without affiliation to any financial institution, regulator, or commercial entity that could have a vested interest in the findings.
declarations.ethicsApproval: No human participants, personal data, or clinical procedures were involved in this study. Therefore, ethical approval was not required.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no external funding. It was conducted entirely on a voluntary basis by the author as a contribution to academic and regulatory understanding of potential structural anomalies in financial markets.

detail.abstract: A forensic investigation into a rare geometric alignment between EUR/USD and the S&P 500 — with a probability of less than one in 7.9 trillion. In 2020–2025, two global markets — the euro-dollar pair and the S&P 500 index — displayed an uncanny sequence of price and time symmetries. This document presents the full analytical breakdown: exact doubling moves, mirrored timing patterns, and statistical deviations below 0.03%. Each event, on its own, is more precise than a human fingerprint. Together, they form a coherent multi-market structure that challenges the assumption of randomness in modern finance. This report is not a trading manual. It is a cross-disciplinary anomaly log — relevant to traders, economists, regulators, and journalists. It raises a single, uncomfortable question: If this was not coincidence, then what was it?

title: The Time Cost of a Disability
affiliations: University of Texas at Austin and Centre for Economic Analysis (CenEA)

detail.title: The Time Cost of a Disability

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: We consider how a physical disability alters patterns of time use. A disability may raise the time cost of all activities; of somemaking them differentially less worth doing; or it may make switching activities more costly. The first yields no predictions about time use, but the latter two possibilities both predict that fewer activities will be undertaken, with more time spent on each. These explanations describe our findings based on non-working ATUS 2008-22 respondents ages 70+, 32 percent of whom self-assess a disability. Data from the Polish Time Use Survey, where disability is medically certified, show similar results; and they demonstrate the same loss of variety over multiple days. Remarkably similar basic results are found using homogenized British, Canadian, French, Spanish, and Italian time-diaries. Overall, a mobility/physical disability leads an otherwise identical person to engage in over 10 percent fewer activities on a typical day. The lost variety represents extra costs equivalent in data from six countries to over twice the average annual income among older individuals in the country.

title: How Do Classmates Matter for the Class-Size Effects?
affiliations: University of Tokyo and Ritsumeikan University

detail.title: How Do Classmates Matter for the Class-Size Effects?

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: This paper investigates the effect of class-size reduction on students academic outcomes, with a particular emphasis on its heterogeneity based on classmates characteristics. We estimate the causal effects of class-size reduction on students mathematics and language test scores by controlling for student and teacher fixed effects. To address potential endogeneity, we employ the predicted class size with a cap as an instrumental variable for the actual class size. Utilizing rich panel data on Japanese primary school students, our findings indicate a positive and robust average effect of class-size reductionon mathematics test scores. Furthermore, we find that classes with high-ability classmates benefit even more from class-size reduction in terms of language test scores. The effect of class-size reduction on mathematics test scores is found to depend positively on the ability of the lowest-achieving student in a class. Additionally, classes with a higher proportion of female students tend to benefit more from class-size reduction. Our results lend support to the theoretical framework proposed by Lazear (2001).

title: AI and Women's Employment in Europe
affiliations: University of Miami, European Central Bank (ECB), Banco de España - Research Department, European Central Bank (ECB) and University of Oxford

detail.title: AI and Women's Employment in Europe
detail.abstract: We examine the link between the diffusion of artificial intelligence (AI) enabled technologies and changes in the female employment share in 16 European countries over the period 2011-2019. Using data for occupations at the 3-digit level, we find that on average female employment shares increased in occupations more exposed to AI. Countries with high initial female labor force participation and higher initial female relative education show a stronger positive association. While there exists heterogeneity across countries, almost all show a positive relation between changes in female employment shares within occupations and exposure to AI-enabled automation.

title: Immigration, Demand, Supply and Sectoral Heterogeneity in the UK Labor Market
affiliations: University of London, Royal Holloway College - Department of Economics and London School of Economics & Political Science (LSE) - Centre for Economic Performance (CEP)

detail.title: Immigration, Demand, Supply and Sectoral Heterogeneity in the UK Labor Market

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: The empirical migration literature often identifies the labor market effects of immigration using exogenous variation of migration concentration across sectors. However, this approach differences out macroeconomic effects which occur in all sectors. We apply macroeconomic time series methods to UK labor market data for 35 different sectors, to model, for the first time, immigration, native wages and hours worked, as responding to demand, supply and immigration shocks at both aggregate and sectoral levels. The labor market is modeled as being subject to multiple shocks at any one time. Using VAR, we find that migrant labor is, in part, endogenously determined by aggregate demand and supply along with an exogenous component. Using historical decompositions which decompose both the error terms and, novelly, the constant terms into their structural parts, we show that the migration shock accounts for most of the change in migration share and has  a significant negative effect on native wage growth, particularly in unskilled sectors.  However other contemporaneous shocks have offsetting positive associations between immigration and native wages, whoe effects differ across sectors

title: Details Matter: Loan Pricing and Transmission of Monetary Policy in the Euro Area
affiliations: Latvijas Banka, European Central Bank, Financial Research Division, Latvijas Banka, Deutsche Bundesbank, Central Bank of Malta, National Bank of Slovakia, Deutsche Bundesbank, National Bank of Slovakia, Bank of Greece, Central Bank of Ireland, Bank of Greece and Latvijas Banka

detail.title: Details Matter: Loan Pricing and Transmission of Monetary Policy in the Euro Area
detail.abstract: Does the maturity of the relevant risk-free rate influence the strength of monetary policy pass-through to interest rates on new loans? To address this question, we present novel empirical evidence on lending practices across all euro area countries, using AnaCredit data covering nearly seven million new loans issued to non-financial corporations in 2022–2023. We document substantial variation in (a) the prevalence of fixed- vs floating-rate loans, (b) rate fixation periods, and (c) reference rates. This variation results in lending rates being exposed to different segments of the risk-free rate yield curve which, in turn, influence their sensitivity to monetary policy changes. We show that loans linked to shorter-maturity risk-free rates experience more pronounced monetary pass-through. Importantly, this effect is not purely mechanical, as part of the effect is offset by adjustments in the premium, revealing previously less-explored heterogeneity in the pass-through to lending rates.

title: Stochastic Commitment in Repeated Games
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Chinese University of Hong Kong and University of Washington

detail.title: Stochastic Commitment in Repeated Games
detail.abstract: We study infinitely repeated games in which players choose automata instead of stage-game actions each period to determine their continuation plays. A key innovation is the introduction of stochastic commitment; at the end of each stage, players face an exogenous probability independently of becoming irrevocably committed to their current automaton in the continuation game. We refer to the resulting equilibrium in this repeated automaton game with stochastic commitment as the stochastic commitment equilibrium (SCE). We show that the classical folk theorem no longer holds in this setting. We fully characterize the set of SCE payoffs when players are sufficiently patient and the probability of commitment is sufficiently small. We show that stochastic commitment restricts the range of equilibrium outcomes relative to standard repeated games and could even lead to a unique prediction in some games. Our framework offers new insights into how commitment frictions shape long-run strategic behaviors.

title: Geospatial Trends and Geochemical Fingerprints Reveal Anthropogenic Enrichment of Phosphorus from Mining in Subalpine Soils
affiliations: Stanford University, Brigham Young University, Brigham Young University and Brigham Young University

detail.title: Geospatial Trends and Geochemical Fingerprints Reveal Anthropogenic Enrichment of Phosphorus from Mining in Subalpine Soils
detail.abstract: Phosphorus is a non-renewable resource essential for all life, yet anthropogenic alterations to the phosphorus cycle and unsustainable management have led to widespread phosphorus pollution and the threat of phosphorus resource depletion. One human alteration to the phosphorus-cycle is phosphate rock mining. Mining can lead to widespread dust emissions. Dust collection near a phosphorus mine in the Ashley National Forest of northeastern Utah has shown dust-phosphorus concentrations more than four times that of other regional samples. This suggests that mining emissions may alter the natural phosphorus loading of the soils in the National Forest through dust deposition; however, no research has been done to identify the abundance and range of mine-attributable phosphorus enrichment in the soils surrounding phosphate mining activities. The combined geospatial and geochemical approach of this study shows that surface soil phosphorus concentrations were found to be enriched above naturally occurring levels up to 8 km from mining activity (enrichment factor > 1.5), with the most significant enrichment occurring within the first 4 km (enrichment factor > 2). On average, surface phosphorus concentrations were significantly enriched by 25% within 8 km of phosphorus mining activity. Observed phosphorus enrichment was positively correlated with the presence of fluorapatite in the soil, the primary phosphorus-mineral extracted from the nearby mine. Further, bioavailable phosphorus was also higher for the soils that were enriched in phosphorus. This study shows that fugitive emissions associated with the surface mining of phosphate rock are a significant source of phosphorus enrichment in subalpine soils.

title: Labile Potassium Dependency and Limited Buffering Capacity in Highly Weathered Loamy and Clay Soils of Southwest Australia Revealed by Q/I Isotherms and K Release
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Murdoch University and Government of Western Australia - Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development

detail.title: Labile Potassium Dependency and Limited Buffering Capacity in Highly Weathered Loamy and Clay Soils of Southwest Australia Revealed by Q/I Isotherms and K Release
detail.abstract: Understanding soil potassium (K) availability is critical for developing K fertilizer recommendations, especially in regions with inherently low soil K reserves. The quantity/intensity isotherm and K release were used to evaluate the dynamics of K in loam-and clay-textured soil types developed from highly weathered parent materials in Western Australia (WA). Twenty-one soil types with a wide range of properties were collected from 0-10, 10-20 and 20-30 cm depths on farmland in WA. The equilibrium activity ratio of K+ varied from 0.1 ´ 10-3 to 45.6 ´ 10-3 (mol L-1)1/2 and was significantly higher in surface soils than subsurface soils. The labile K (KL) ranged from 0.03 to 2.18 cmol/kg, and the contributions of non-specifically held K towards KL were > 50% in surface soils but lesser in subsoils. The potential buffering capacity (PBCK) ranged from 5.4 to 185 cmol kg-1 (mol L-1)-1/2 and was significantly correlated with soil effective cation exchange capacity (ECEC), pH and clay content. It can be predicted by ECEC as PBCK = 6.78 + 3.72 ECEC (R2 = 0.95). The cumulative amounts of K released after 213 h ranged from 27 to 833 mg/kg, with a rapid release of K up to 22 h followed by a gradual release until the end. In conclusion, most soils, especially surface soils, had adequate K availability for crop production but it is vulnerable to losses and depletion. Given the overall low ECEC and PBCK, split or delayed K applications are recommended, alongside practices that enhance K buffering capacity in WA soils.

title: Hedging and Net Worth: Evidence from Purchase Obligations
affiliations: Babson College

detail.title: Hedging and Net Worth: Evidence from Purchase Obligations
detail.abstract: Manufacturing rms depend on commodity inputs for their production processes, which leads them to engage in hedging strategies to mitigate the impact of commodity price uctuations. In particular, they regularly employ supply contracts that feature xed prices, which are also known as purchase obligations in the literature. This paper documents a weak correlation between nancial hedging and net worth for publicly traded companies in the manufacturing sector in the United States. These ndings remain robust even when accounting for various rm characteristics, including size and commodity exposure. The empirical evidence presented may appear to challenge contemporary corporate hedging theories that highlight collateral as a key determinant of hedging decisions. However, I show that these theories align with the ndings of this paper when rms have su cient collateral, revealing a satiation point in the relationship between net worth and hedging.

title: Bias Correction of Superficial Circulation with Cnn-Lstm and Hf-Radar Data in Southwest South Atlantic
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Bias Correction of Superficial Circulation with Cnn-Lstm and Hf-Radar Data in Southwest South Atlantic
detail.abstract: This study explores the application of a Convolutional Long Short-Term Memory (CNN-LSTM) neural network to correct surface current velocity fields from a global ocean model using high-frequency radar (HF-Radar) observations. The model performance was evaluated across different regions of the Brazil Current, off southestern Brazil region, with a focus on reducing systematic biases and improving model accuracy. Results demonstrate that the CNN-LSTM network effectively corrected both the zonal (U) and meridional (V) components of the current, with more significant improvements observed in the V component. The neural network consistently reduced RMSE, bias, and increased Pearson correlation, outperforming a benchmark linear regression model. The spatial analysis highlighted that the neural network correction significantly reduced errors in areas with large discrepancies, particularly in regions along the axis of Brazil Current. This study suggests that hybrid modelling with neural networks can enhance the accuracy of ocean circulation predictions, offering a valuable tool for post-processing numerical ocean models, even in regions with complex mesoscale features.

title: Large Banks and Endogenous Credit Cycles
affiliations: Shanghai University of Finance and Economics - Department of Finance

detail.title: Large Banks and Endogenous Credit Cycles
detail.abstract: We propose a tractable dynamic general equilibrium model incorporated with an oligopolistic banking sector that consists of a finite number of non-atomic banks. We investigate how the degree of bank concentration can affect strategic interactions among banks and financial stability. In the model, bank lending is constrained by the market value of firms' collateral; however, more bank lending leads to more economic activities, which raises the value of firms' collateral. Due to the feedback effects between bank lending and collateral value, there can be multiple equilibria: a Good equilibrium with higher collateral value and more lending and a Bad equilibrium with lower collateral value and less lending. Larger banks could better internalize the effect of their lending policies on collateral value, contributing towards eliminating the Bad equilibrium and raising stability. The model can generate endogenous boom-bust credit cycles, with the frequency of credit cycles depending negatively on the level of bank concentration.

title: Geochemical Evolution of the Mineralizing Fluids at the Tenke-Fungurume Mining District (Dr Congo): Insights from Microthermometry, Crush-Leach, and La-Icp-Ms Analyses of Fluid Inclusions
affiliations: KU Leuven, KU Leuven and KU Leuven

detail.title: Geochemical Evolution of the Mineralizing Fluids at the Tenke-Fungurume Mining District (Dr Congo): Insights from Microthermometry, Crush-Leach, and La-Icp-Ms Analyses of Fluid Inclusions
detail.abstract: The Tenke-Fungurume mining district, located in the northern part of the Katanga Copperbelt, DR Congo, hosts numerous carbonate-quartz veins that demonstrate the pre-, syn-, and post-folding events related to the Lufilian Orogeny. Microthermometric and geochemical analyses of their contained fluid inclusions were performed to understand the fluid evolution throughout those stages. Primary fluid inclusions record a large range of Th (149-372°C) and salinity (37.1-59.9 wt.% NaCl + KCl eq.) for all stages, which cannot be used to differentiate between successive events. Laser ablation ICP-MS and crush-leach analysis invariably point to fluids originating from the progressive evaporation of seawater. Fluid chemistry was strongly controlled by intense fluid-rock interactions at high temperatures. All dolomite samples show major recrystallization patterns and phases, which testify to fluid flow events that likely affected the whole Katanga basin. High contents of Cu, Co, Ba, Zn, and Pb relative to Na were measured in primary fluid inclusions of all stages, suggesting mineralization was not restricted to discrete or unique events, but rather that the same hydrothermal ore-forming system operated over a long period during basin evolution and deformation.

title: Impact of Riparian Zone Alterations on Crop Productivity in Diamphwe River Basin
affiliations: Tokyo University of Agriculture, Lilongwe University of Agriculture and Natural Resources, Japan International Research Center for Agricultural Sciences (JIRCAS), Hokkaido University, Tokyo University of Agriculture, Tokyo University of Agriculture and Tokyo University of Agriculture

detail.title: Impact of Riparian Zone Alterations on Crop Productivity in Diamphwe River Basin
detail.abstract: Irrigation is vital for crop production, yet its potential is underutilised in many river basins. In Malawi, crop production is predominantly reliant on rainfall, making it vulnerable to climate change and natural disasters. This study evaluates the irrigation potential and crop production trends in the Diamphwe River Basin, a key agricultural watershed, using remote sensing and soil analysis. Sentinel-2 data, maize production records from the Lilongwe Agricultural Development Division (ADD), and field surveys conducted at 15 randomly selected points within a 2 km buffer on either side of the river were utilised in the study. Findings indicate that irrigated maize exhibits higher productivity than rainfed maize, suggesting that harnessing irrigation could serve as a suitable alternative to the unreliable rainfed production in the basin, particularly within the 100-1000 m buffer zones that have greater irrigation potential. Kabwazi EPA accounted for 29% and 33% of the basin’s irrigable land in 2017 and 2024, respectively, due to its strategic positioning within the basin. The riparian zone displays medium hydraulic conductivity (HC), indicating suitable soils (luvisol) for infiltration, pollutant removal, and groundwater recharge, which are essential for sustaining river flow. Despite increased productivity, the impact of irrigation on maize remains minimal due to low participation by large-scale farmers and insufficient extension services, as evidenced by the underutilisation of potentially irrigable land (162.5 km2 in 2017 and 145.4 km2 in 2024). The study underscores the necessity for targeted policy interventions to optimise irrigation and enhance agricultural productivity and water resource management.

title: Carbon Overhang Valuing Corporate Exposure to Future Carbon Costs
affiliations: University of California, Berkeley - Haas School of Business, Dimensional Fund Advisors and University of California, Berkeley - Haas School of Business

detail.title: Carbon Overhang Valuing Corporate Exposure to Future Carbon Costs
detail.abstract: This study develops a forward-looking valuation framework to quantify firm-level exposure to future carbon costs. We introduce the Carbon Overhang (COH) metric, defined as the present value of future carbon costs based on firm-level emissions projections and jurisdiction-specific carbon prices. Applying this framework to U.S.-listed firms, we estimate a market-level COH of $2.4 to $4.1 trillion—equivalent to 5% to 9% of total market capitalization. The distribution of COH is highly concentrated, with the top 25 firms—mainly utilities and energy companies—accounting for over half of the total. Still, we find substantial variation within sectors, driven by differences in operational structure and emissions geography. Adjusting for carbon cost pass-through from upstream energy providers reallocates up to 70% of the COH away from regulated utilities and toward downstream customers. Importantly, even under the most ambitious policy scenario, we find that prevailing and anticipated carbon pricing mechanisms are expected to internalize only about half of the societal damages from corporate emissions. Overall, our framework underscores the importance of forward-looking and location-specific emissions and carbon price forecasts as essential inputs for integrating carbon risk into financial analysis and valuation.

title: How Electric Load Responds to Temperature and Weather Variables in Texas
affiliations: University of Missouri

detail.title: How Electric Load Responds to Temperature and Weather Variables in Texas
detail.abstract: I demonstrate how electric load in Texas responds to temperature and other meteorological variables, depicting hourly characteristics. Using a exible Fourier framework, I estimate cross-temperature response functions (CTRFs) and hence the marginal responses/partial effects of weather conditions. Time-of-day variations are significant for estimated response functions and load gradient on temperatures. While the sectoral and behavioral switches are figured out from reasoning, the CTRF model unravels temporal changes and corroborates the interplay of weather variables, disentangling nuanced diurnal and seasonal heterogeneity. In Dallas-Fort Worth, for example, relative humidity and sky cover mainly amplify perceived thermal discomfort and thus have opposite impacts on cooling and heating demand for different seasons and temperature spans. Wind speed serves as a cooler in both summer and winter, while taking effect primarily at night and early hours. Their impact on the contemporaneous load has a similar magnitude with respective one standard deviation changes, about 2--5% at maximum times. These findings improve upon prior studies by capturing time-sensitive and weather-sensitive demand. The proposed approach provides a useful tool for modeling hourly electric load and can inform adaptive strategies for electrical grids in diverse regions and climates.

detail.title: How Electric Load Responds to Temperature and Weather Variables in Texas
detail.abstract: I demonstrate how electric load in Texas responds to temperature and other meteorological variables, depicting hourly characteristics. Using a exible Fourier framework, I estimate cross-temperature response functions (CTRFs) and hence the marginal responses/partial effects of weather conditions. Time-of-day variations are significant for estimated response functions and load gradient on temperatures. title: Carbon Overhang Valuing Corporate Exposure to Future Carbon Costs
affiliations: University of California, Berkeley - Haas School of Business, Dimensional Fund Advisors and University of California, Berkeley - Haas School of Business

detail.title: Carbon Overhang Valuing Corporate Exposure to Future Carbon Costs
detail.abstract: This study develops a forward-looking valuation framework to quantify firm-level exposure to future carbon costs. We introduce the Carbon Overhang (COH) metric, defined as the present value of future carbon costs based on firm-level emissions projections and jurisdiction-specific carbon prices. Applying this framework to U.S.-listed firms, we estimate a market-level COH of $2.4 to $4.1 trillion—equivalent to 5% to 9% of total market capitalization. The distribution of COH is highly concentrated, with the top 25 firms—mainly utilities and energy companies—accounting for over half of the total. Still, we find substantial variation within sectors, driven by differences in operational structure and emissions geography. Adjusting for carbon cost pass-through from upstream energy providers reallocates up to 70% of the COH away from regulated utilities and toward downstream customers. Importantly, even under the most ambitious policy scenario, we find that prevailing and anticipated carbon pricing mechanisms are expected to internalize only about half of the societal damages from corporate emissions. Overall, our framework underscores the importance of forward-looking and location-specific emissions and carbon price forecasts as essential inputs for integrating carbon risk into financial analysis and valuation.

title: Improvement of Carbon Price Prediction with Social Factors and Mixed-Frequency Unstructured Data

detail.title: Improvement of Carbon Price Prediction with Social Factors and Mixed-Frequency Unstructured Data
detail.abstract: Carbon emissions trading right is one of core financial instruments for climate risk management, and carbon trading price prediction can be an effective tool. The introduction of social factor data, effective processing of high-dimensional data, and prediction methods improvement are still in great need in current study. With the examples of carbon emission rights trading prices in China's markets, we aim to further solve these issues: (1) First, we intrude the social policy of sentiment index and Baidu search index as influencing factors, and effectively deal with such unstructured data. The results show that they act as important factors in four carbon trading markets. (2) Second, by screening key indicators and combining the mixed frequency dynamic factor model (MF-DFM), we explore the overall influence of the typical external factors on carbon prices and forecast the volatility of the carbon price. (3) Third, deep neural network (DNN) models are added to predict diligently the residual, and the effect of deep learning model and method on improving the forecasting accuracy is discussed. Our study has further improved the factor system that affects carbon trading prices and proposed more predictive methods, which can have certain reference value for carbon emission trading management.

title: Efficient Concentration of Lithium Ions from Various Types of Brine Using Freeze-Thaw Method

detail.title: Efficient Concentration of Lithium Ions from Various Types of Brine Using Freeze-Thaw Method
detail.abstract: In response to the ecological vulnerability and extreme climate challenges faced in the development of lithium resources in salt lakes on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, this study proposes a brine concentration process for salt lakes based on the principle of eutectic freezing, taking advantage of the regional natural cold energy.The saturation point temperature was optimized through the Universal Quasi–Chemical Model, and the freezing temperature (-15 to -24℃), time (2 to 4 h), and stirring rate (0 to 1000 r/min) were systematically optimized. Under the optimal experimental conditions, the brine with a low magnesium-lithium ratio (Zabuye Lake, Mg/Li=0.053) was frozen and thawed at 10 levels, and the concentration of Li+ reached 5.196 g/L, enriched by 106.26 times. The brine with a high magnesium-lithium ratio (Yiliping Lake, Mg/Li=60.95) was processed through 13 stages of freeze-thaw, with the Li+ concentration reaching 5.182 g/L, enriched by 246.76 times, and simultaneously recovering Na+, K+, and Mg2+.The freezing temperature and time significantly affect the growth of ice crystals and the solute distribution coefficient. This method combines the characteristics of low pollution and ecological friendliness, providing theoretical support and technical paths for the green development of lithium resources in the Qinghai-Tibet salt lakes.

title: Water-Energy-Food-Ghg Nexus-Based Optimization of Irrigation and Nitrogen Strategies for Sustainable Intensification of Indian Mustard in Hot Arid Region of India

detail.title: Water-Energy-Food-Ghg Nexus-Based Optimization of Irrigation and Nitrogen Strategies for Sustainable Intensification of Indian Mustard in Hot Arid Region of India
detail.abstract: Water, energy, food, and the environment are strongly interconnected in agricultural systems, and understanding these linkages is essential for promoting sustainable crop production. This study applies a water-energy-food-greenhouse gas (WEFG) nexus framework to Indian mustard (Brassica juncea L.) production in arid India to evaluate the effects of deficit irrigation, nitrogen (N) rates, and bio-regulators (BRs) on agro-economic and environmental performance, and aimed to identify optimal input combinations that balance productivity, profitability, and emissions reduction.  A three-year field experiment tested three irrigation levels [full (FI, 100% ETc), moderate deficit (MDI, 70% ETc), and severe deficit (SDI, 40% ETc)], three N rates (40, 80, 120 kg N ha⁻¹), and three BR treatments [without  BR, thiourea (500 ppm), and salicylic acid (0.5 mM)]. Key energy and emission sources included electricity for irrigation, fertilizers and diesel. Compared to full irrigation (FI), MDI reduced water (25%), energy (15%), and GHG emissions (18%) with minimal yield loss and improved resourceefficiencies. Higher N rates under FI and MDI increased yield and input productivity but also raised emissions; under SDI, higher N lowered water and energy productivity. BR application, especially thiourea, enhanced yields and resource use efficiencies without notably increasing emissions. The combination of MDI, with 120 kg N, and thiourea application had highest WEFG index, indicating optimal balance among productivity, efficiency, and environmental performance. The WEFG nexus framework proved effective in capturing trade-offs and synergies across resource use, profitability, and emissions, offering a robust tool to identify sustainable crop management strategies aligned with the Sustainable Development Goals.

title: Innovation and Infrastructure: Charting Syria’s Tech-Driven Future

detail.title: Innovation and Infrastructure: Charting Syria’s Tech-Driven Future
detail.abstract:
"Innovation and Infrastructure: Charting Syria’s Tech-Driven Future" provides a comprehensive blueprint for integrating advanced digital technologies into Syria's core economic sectors to drive sustainable growth and enhance global competitiveness. This book carefully examines the current state of Syria’s agriculture, industry, healthcare, education, and fintech sectors, identifying key areas where technology can play a transformative role.

The text proposes a detailed strategic plan for digital transformation, emphasizing the development of robust infrastructures, the adaptation of educational systems to meet technological demands, and the creation of supportive policy frameworks. It explores how digital tools and innovations such as artificial intelligence, robotics, and automation can be leveraged to improve efficiency, productivity, and service delivery across all sectors.

The book draws on global trends and successful case studies to propose a localized approach that is both visionary and practical. It offers a five-year roadmap for technological integration, featuring investment analyses, potential funding sources, and projected returns, along with risk assessments and mitigation strategies to ensure that these plans are viable under various economic conditions.

Aimed at policymakers, industry leaders, and the international community, "Innovation and Infrastructure" calls for collaborative efforts to foster a technological renaissance in Syria, making it a vital resource for anyone committed to the country’s future as a leader in digital innovation in the Middle East. This book not only serves as a strategic guide but also as a call to action to empower Syria through the thoughtful integration of technology in its developmental agenda.

title: A Comprehensive Insight for Platform-Based Labour Dispute Resolution in China's New Employment Forms
affiliations: University of Melbourne, Law School

detail.title: A Comprehensive Insight for Platform-Based Labour Dispute Resolution in China's New Employment Forms
detail.abstract: With the rapid development of new employment models in China, platform-based employment has emerged as a significant form of employment. Platform-based employment models are diverse. Characteristics and operational mechanisms differ among each model. In labour-relationship-based models, also known as the 'employ-employee' model, workers have a relatively close subordinate relationship with platform companies, while civil-cooperation-based model involve collaboration between companies and workers based on equal civil subject status. Meanwhile, the quasiemployment relationship model falls between traditional labour relationships and civil relationships, with workers having a relatively weaker subordinate relationship. However, while this model provides workers with flexible employment opportunities, it also poses significant challenges in terms of rights protection, particularly regarding disputes between workers and platforms. Such disputes not only increase in number each year but also have complex causes, including outdated laws and regulations, unclear standards for determining labour relationships, ambiguous definitions of platform company responsibilities, weak awareness of worker rights, and inadequate dispute resolution mechanisms. In handling these disputes, courts, lawyers, and platform companies face challenges such as difficulty in determining legal relationships, high barriers to evidence collection, and diverse claims. These issues urgently require solutions through measures such as improving laws and regulations, strengthening platform responsibility, and enhancing workers' awareness of their rights. This article aims to comprehensively analyse the current status, characteristics, and causes of platform employment disputes under the new employment landscape, examine the operational mechanisms and legal risks of different platform employment models, and through the analysis of typical cases, summarise the courts' judicial reasoning and adjudication criteria, as well as successful dispute resolution experiences. This article seeks to provide targeted solutions and guidelines for both platform companies and workers to address these challenges.

title: Omega - an Open-Economy Multi-Sector Endogenous-Growth Assessment Model for Development Policy Analysis

detail.title: Omega - an Open-Economy Multi-Sector Endogenous-Growth Assessment Model for Development Policy Analysis
detail.abstract: This paper presents OMEGA, a dynamic stochastic structural model for analyzing policy trade-offs in emerging markets. It includes essential features not found in standard models: household heterogeneity with distinct asset holdings, wealth in utility, endogenous growth through education, working capital needs, borrowing limits, and endogenous risk premia reflecting financial frictions and weak rule of law. Estimated for Türkiye, OMEGA assesses monetary, fiscal, structural, and climate policies, replicating standard responses to shocks. Simulations of a broad variety of climate policy interventions reveal significant interaction effects, and results show weak policy credibility increases transition costs by delaying investment. OMEGA offers a robust framework for evaluating development policies in emerging markets.

title: Women's Agency and Intra-Household Efficiency
affiliations: Colgate University, Colgate University and Brown University

detail.title: Women's Agency and Intra-Household Efficiency
detail.abstract: We present results from an experiment with married couples in Western Kenya, who play five rounds of a voluntary contributions game. Spouses allocate an endowment between a private account and a household account earning 50 percent interest. We add a randomized first stage where women either allocate the endowment or choose whether to defer the decision to their husbands. Thirty-five percent defer in at least one round. These women receive smaller endowments and contribute less to the household account. Efficiency is higher when women exert agency. Deference is also associated with higher exposure to intimate partner violence.

title: Spatiotemporal Estimation of Actively Shedding Mpox Virus, Clade Iib, Cases Using Wastewater Signals in British Columbia, Canada

detail.title: Spatiotemporal Estimation of Actively Shedding Mpox Virus, Clade Iib, Cases Using Wastewater Signals in British Columbia, Canada
detail.abstract: Wastewater surveillance programs collect sewage influent to monitor for pathogens or chemical signatures. Using wastewater surveillance to detect viral genetic material can offer less biased prevalence estimates of viral infections than test or case-based surveillance systems, but existing methods often overlook key factors like spatiotemporal autocorrelation and the duration of viral shedding. Here, we incorporate wastewater signals within a hierarchical Bayesian spatiotemporal model to estimate active mpox cases, defined as individuals who are actively shedding the virus. Our model allows for estimation of active mpox cases within community health service areas, the most precise geographical level of health administration in British Columbia, Canada over time. The inclusion of a time-varying wastewater signal improved the model fit to active cases (WAIC = 3569, Δ 51). The mean absolute error of mpox active cases was ~ 2 cases (95%CI, 1-4) per community health service area. Our study demonstrates the use of hierarchical Bayesian spatiotemporal models as essential tools in wastewater-based infectious diseases surveillance, emphasizing the importance of spatial and temporal autocorrelation in understanding the patterns in both wastewater signals and actively shedding mpox cases.

title: A Unified Explanation of Reference Dependence, Loss Aversion, and the Reflection Effect
affiliations: University of London, Royal Holloway College - Department of Economics

detail.title: A Unified Explanation of Reference Dependence, Loss Aversion, and the Reflection Effect
detail.abstract: This paper explains four features of behavioral economics -- reference dependence, loss aversion, concave utility for gains, and convex utility for losses -- as properties of a single incomplete preference relation.  A single preference makes it possible to compare an agent's welfare at different dates.  The preference relation will arise when an agent chooses an alternative over the status quo only if the agent's `candidate' preferences unanimously approve the change.  The set of candidates must be rich enough to include, for any subset of goods, both preferences that are more optimistic towards these goods than the other candidates and preferences that are less optimistic.  Greater optimism obtains when a good's marginal rate of substitution relative to other goods is larger and diminishes less rapidly.  Existing accounts of the same phenomena invoke several underlying psychological mechanisms and cannot compare an agent's welfare across time.

title: Alter: A Deep Meta-Optimization Model with Learning Spatial-Temporal-Random Information for Time Series Forecasting
affiliations: Shandong University of Science and Technology, Shandong University of Science and Technology and Shandong University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Alter: A Deep Meta-Optimization Model with Learning Spatial-Temporal-Random Information for Time Series Forecasting
detail.abstract: In the Transformer-dominated era, meta-optimization frameworks have shown promise for time series forecasting though they face challenges in capturing intrinsic characteristics, including temporal dependencies, spatial correlations, and randomness. These limitations impede effective modeling of complex patterns, prompting the need for a more robust approach.Therefore, the paper proposes Alter, a hierarchical framework to overcome these limitations. The methodology first applies Concatenated Fourier Features (CFF) to transform the original sequence into a feature space that enhances pattern detectability. This is followed by the Spatial-Temporal-Random Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) for extracting intrinsic characteristics and the Ridge Regressor that produces accurate forecasts.The Spatial-Temporal-Random MLP integrates three key innovations: (1) Alterable Kernel Convolution (AKConv) is improved to Spatial AKConv, strengthening feature correlations across spatial dimensions. (2) A lightweight Efficient Gated Unit is designed to effectively capture both long-term and short-term dependencies, addressing the temporal modeling gap. (3) Random Implicit Neural Representation (INR) is proposed to extract randomness, a critical component often overlooked in traditional models.Experiments show Alter performs better than state-of-the-art (SOTA) models, with average improvements of 5.07%, 3.66%, and 3.99% in multivariate, univariate, and few-shot tasks, respectively.The code is available in https://github.com/weirdoZHANG/Alter.

detail.title: Generalized Regression Under Orthogonality Constraints: A Low-Rank Approach to Unsupervised Feature Selectio
detail.abstract: Traditional regression models face significant challenges, including susceptibility to overfitting and computational inefficiency. To address these challenges, this paper presents an orthogonality constrained low-rank generalized regression model for unsupervised feature selection. The proposed model introduces a low-rank regularization to reduce the computational complexity while maintaining effective modeling capability for key features. Moreover, we decompose the regression coefficient matrix into a low-rank approximation matrix and a sparse error matrix, thereby achieving simplification and sparsity of the regression relationship. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed model in  terms of six evaluations metrics by comparing with the state-of-the-art methods.

detail.title: Gfn-Mse: Gated Fusion Network with Modality-Specific Enhancement for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis

detail.abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) leverages text, visual, and audio modalities for sentiment recognition and has become a widely studied field in recent years. Because each modality (e.g., visual and audio) exhibits its own distinctive characteristics, effectively enhancing modality specific representations and designingahigh-quality fusionframeworkremainkeychallengesfor improving overall performance. To address these issues, we propose the Gated Fusion Network with Modality-Specific Enhancement (GFN-MSE). Our model introduces modality-specific prompt information to optimize individual modality features and thereby enhance multimodal fusion. Wefirstconstructsamodalityfeatureextractionmoduletogeneratecorrespondingfeature representations from the text, visual, and audio modalities. Next, we design a modality-specific enhancement module that refines the quality of each modality’s features prior to fusion. Lastly, we introduce a gated fusion network that adaptively balances the contributions of each modality to achieve robust multimodal fusion. We validate GFN-MSE on three standard datasets–CMU MOSI, CMU-MOSEI, and CH-SIMS–and the results show that our approach consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art (SOTA) baselines across all evaluation metrics.

title: Towards Biodiversity Restoration in Degraded Waters: Rebuilding Algae Communities in Post-Mining Ditches

detail.title: Towards Biodiversity Restoration in Degraded Waters: Rebuilding Algae Communities in Post-Mining Ditches
detail.abstract: Algae, as organisms known to occur in extreme environments and accumulate pollutants, can be effective in purifying post-mining waters. Algal flora, for the first time sampled from two post-mining ditches in the area of Upper Silesia (Southern Poland), is characterized by low biodiversity. In this study, we examined the possibility of using mainly autochthonous (indigenous) diatoms and green algal strains from these two ditches, but also some allochthonous green and xanthophyte algal strains from a sewage treatment plant, as so-called biological starters. The use of biological starters, i.e. algal mats growing on solid substrate, prepared in laboratory conditions for placement in post-mining waters, is a new method developed to increase their biodiversity and accelerate purification processes. The rate of biological mass increase for individual algal strains, both one-celled and filamentous, growing together on solid substrate as examined in the water collected from the two ditches under experimental laboratory conditions. Several autochtonous one-celled diatoms, especially Pinnularia appendiculata, and filamentous green algae, Klebsormidium sp. and Mougeotia sp., as well as one allochtonous one-celled green alga, Tetradesmus lagerheimii, turned out to be the most resistant to the conditions prevailing in both ditches, and at the same time the most suitable for inhabiting this type of habitats. These algal taxa were the most important element in the structure of biological starters on solid substrates. Next, the potential of the biological starters to bioaccumulate chemical compounds occurring in elevated concentrations in degraded mine watercourses should be investigated.
